a b s t r a c t
Little is known about the interaction of nanoparticles (NPs) with soil constituents and their effects in plants. Boron (B), an essential micronutrient that reduces crop production at both deficiency and excess, has not been investigated with respect to its interaction with cerium oxide NPs (nano-CeO2). Considering conflicting results on the nano-CeO2 toxicity and protective role as antioxidant, their possible modulation on B toxicity in sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) was investigated. Sunflower was cultivated for 30 days in garden pots containing original or B-spiked soil amended with nano-CeO2 at 0e800 mg kg
1. At harvest, Ce and B concentrations in tissues, biomass, and activities of stress enzymes in leaves were determined. Results showed that in the original soil, Ce accumulated mainly in roots, with little translocation to stems and leaves, while reduced root Ce was observed in plants from B-spiked soil. In the original soil, higher levels of nano-CeO2 reduced plant B concentration. Although morphological effects were not visible, changes in biomass and oxidative stress response were observed. Sunflower leaves from B-spiked soil showed visible symptoms of B toxicity, such as necrosis and chlorosis in old leaves, as well as an increase of superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity. However, at high nano-CeO2 level, SOD activity decreased reaching values similar to that of the control. This study has shown that nano-CeO2 reduced both the B nutritional status of sunflower in original soil and the B phytotoxicity in B-spiked soil.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The increasing production and use of engineered nanoparticles (NPs) in consumer products and other applications, such as environmental remediation, agriculture, and pharmacology, lead to their release in the environment. Once in the soil or water, they may be taken up by living organisms, enter into the food chain, persist in different environmental matrixes for extended periods, cause ecotoxicological hazards, and bioaccumulate in the food chain (Rico et al., 2011; Baalousha et al., 2016). Thus, it is important to recognize the consequences of the use of nanomaterials and

their interactionwith soil components, water, and living organisms. Soil represents an important sink for NPs, since their accumulation could occur after the end user application of nano-enabled products, their presence in fertilizers, plant protection products, and soil amendments (Servin and White, 2016). Moreover, edible plants are considered the point of entry for their bioaccumulation in the food chain.
Cerium oxide nanoparticles (CeO2 NPs, nano-CeO2) are used in a variety of applications comprising solid oxide fuel cells, environmental remediation, mechanical polishing, sensing, catalysis, and biomedicine (Andreescu et al., 2014). The soil-plant system has been exposed to CeO2 NPs, showing effects in the status of nutrients and physiological processes. Gui et al. (2015) reported a significant increase of nitrate content and disruption of the activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), and malondialdehyde
ical responses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) exposed to nanoPhysiology and Biochemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
(MDA) in Lactuca sativa exposed to 100 and 1000 mg kg 1 nanoCeO2 in soil, respectively. Rico et al. (2013a,b,c and 2015) reported that nano-CeO2 produced a significant modification in the antioxidant system of rice (Oryza sativa) and a negative impact on rice grain quality. In addition, previous studies have shown that plants take up and store nano-CeO2 in different tissues (L opez-Moreno et al., 2010; Zhang et al., 2012; Hernandez-Viezcas et al., 2013). Later investigations suggested that nano-CeO2 may release Ce3þ on the root surface, which uptakes both the Ce3þ ions and the nanoCeO2 (Gui et al., 2015; Ma et al., 2015; Schwabe et al., 2015).
Recent studies have shown conflicting results on the biological impact of nano-CeO2, varying from toxicity to protective effects, due to their role as antioxidant/free-radical scavenger (Rico et al., 2015). Most of the exciting and harmful properties of nano-CeO2 derive from the switching between Ce3þ and Ce4þ oxidation states of NPs and their surface adsorption properties (Andreescu et al., 2014). It has been stated that smaller CeO2 NPs have higher surface-to-volume ratio and number of defects in their crystalline structure, which have been considered themain factors responsible for increasing the Ce3þ/Ce4þ ratio (Loschen et al., 2008). The switching reaction between Ce cations has been associated with the SOD and catalase (CAT) mimetic activities of nano-CeO2 (Celardo et al., 2011). The chemical reduction of superoxide requires high Ce3þ/Ce4þ ratio, due to the ability of Ce3þ to get oxidized producing peroxide, a reaction that corresponds to the reduction of superoxide by SOD, hence termed SOD-mimetic. On the other hand, low Ce3þ/Ce4þ ratio favors the process of oxidation of H2O2 by reacting with Ce4þ, producing reduced Ce and molecular O2, a reaction similar to that of CAT. The spontaneous switching from the oxidized to the reduced state could produce a mechanism of regeneration of nano-CeO2, which could work as an ideal antioxidant, scavenging two types of reactive oxygen species (ROS): (O2 and H2O2). However, it is still not clear whether, and in which conditions, nano-CeO2 promote ROS generation or ROS scavenging.
Boron (B) is an essential micronutrient characterized by a narrow range between deficiency and excess, both producing toxic symptoms that affect crop production (Da Silva Leonardo et al., 2016). Although B requirement varies among crops, the optimum B content for most crops is 20e100 mg kg 1. Its excess can result in plant toxicity, while its deficiency causes large losses in crop production and crop quality.
Our previous studies have shown that the excess of B from contaminated soil causes oxidative stress in sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) (Giansoldati et al., 2012; Tassi et al., 2011). On the other hand, B deficiency in plants affects vegetative and reproductive growth, resulting in inhibition of cell expansion, death of meristems, reduced fertility, and oxidative stress. Studies in B-deficient sunflower have shown ROS generation and changes in antioxidant enzyme activities, resulting in oxidative damage (Cakmak and Romheld, 1997; El-Shinthnawy, 1999).
Sunflower seed oil represents one of the largest source of vegetable oil. Sunflower is used as forage and sunflower oil has several industrial applications, e.g. soap and detergents (Myers, 2002). However, sunflower is one of the most sensitive plants to the deficiency and excess of B (Blamey et al., 1997; Asad et al., 2003).
This study was performed with sunflower plants cultivated in farm soil, spiked or unspikedwith B, to evaluate the effects of nanoCeO2 amendment on plant B homeostasis and phytotoxicity. Considering the conflicting results on the biological impact of nano-CeO2, i.e. toxicity and protective role as antioxidant and freeradical scavenger, the possible modulation of B toxicity was also investigated. In addition to evaluating Ce and B accumulation in the different plant tissues, the activity of stress enzymes was also analyzed. To our knowledge, this is the first report showing the
Please cite this article in press as: Tassi, E., et al., Physiological and bioche CeO2 and excess boron: Modulation of boron phytotoxicity, Plant j.plaphy.2016.09.013
implications of nano-CeO2 on B nutritional status of sunflower plants.

sections.heading: 2.1. CeO2 nanoparticles characteristics
sections.text: The nano-CeO2 used in this study were obtained from the University of California Center for Environmental Implications of Nanotechnology (UC CEIN), through The University of Texas at El Paso, United States. These NPs were previously characterized as having a primary size of 8 ± 1 nm, hydrodynamic size of 1373 ± 32 nm, and zeta potential of 0.62 ± 2.9 mV (pH ¼ 5.8) (Keller et al., 2010; Zhao et al., 2012). Size and zeta potential of NPs suspended in deionized water at 25 mg L 1 were measured using a Malvern Zetasizer (Nano-ZS 90, Malvern) with three determinations per sample, consisting of 12 runs per determination.

sections.heading: 2.2. Soil collection and characterization
sections.text: Top soil (20e30 cm) was collected from an agricultural area in Tuscany, Italy; air-dried, sieved (0e2 mm), and homogenized for characterization and preparation of pot trials. The soil properties [pH, cation exchange capacity (CEC), organic matter (OM), electrical conductivity (EC), texture (clay, silt, and sand fractions)], and essential element contents (N, P, K, Ca, Mg, B) were determined according to the procedure reported in Methods of Soil Analysis (SSSA, 1996). In short, the pH was determined using a glass electrode in a suspension with soil/water ratio of 1:2.5 w/v; CEC using barium acetate; OM by oxidation with potassium dichromate (Walkley-Black method), and texture by the pipette method, using sodium hexametaphosphate as a dispersant. Boron analysis in soil was performed after digestionwith a mixture of H2O2 and HNO3 (v/ v, 1:2.5). The digestion was carried out in polytetrafluoroethylenetetra-fluoromethoxil (PTEF-TFM) pressure digestion vessels in a microwave oven (FKV-ETHOS 900) according to themethod 3051-A (US-EPA, 1995). Digested soil samples were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Varian Liberty Axial) and results were expressed as the mean of four replicates on a dry weight basis.

sections.heading: 2.3. Set up of pot trials and plant analysis
sections.text:
A portion of the collected soil was spiked with an aqueous solution of B to simulate a contamination level of about 20 mg/kg of B available to plants. A soil paste formed with addition of the B solution was air dried and occasionally mixed until the excess of water evaporated. The mixing process was repeated every 10 days for about one month for equilibration and to obtain a uniform distribution of the element. The original control soil was also submitted to the same wet-and-dry procedure with only water, to maintain the same conditions.
A portion of both B-spiked and native (unspiked) soil was treated with the nano-CeO2 suspensions. Suspensions of nanoCeO2 were obtained by adding the required amount of powder to ultra-pure milli-Q water (18 MU cm, Merck Millipore) in order to obtain the nominal concentrations of 100, 200, 400, and 800 mg kg 1 soil. The NP suspensions were prepared by sonication for 30 min in continuous mode with an output power of 80 W (Sonifier 250, Branson). Suspensions were immediately added to the soil by mixing with a mechanical mixer for about 10 min and left to equilibrate for 24 h. To ensure comparable conditions, portions of control and B-spiked soils not treated with the NPs were exposed to the same procedure. To avoid misunderstanding on terminology, the term ‘spiked’ refers to B-spiked soil and the term
mical responses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) exposed to nanoPhysiology and Biochemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
‘treated’ to soil amendedwith NP suspensions, spiked or notwith B. Plastic pots (10 cm height, 12 cm diameter) were filled with 300 g (DW) of: i) control soil (any additive); ii) B-spiked soil; iii) treated soil; and iv) B-spiked and treated soil and sown with four seeds (Paola variety) per pot. Each treatment was replicated four times (total of 40 planted pots). Sunflower plants grew for about 35 d in controlled growth chamber conditions (day/night photoperiod 16/8 h, light intensity of 300 mmol m 2 s 1, day/night temperature of 25/20 C and constant humidity of 70%). Pots were wateredwith tap water whenever needed. At the end of the growth period, plants were collected, severed into roots, stems, and leaves, and exhaustively washed with tap water and rinsed with deionized water. In order to eliminate any further soil particle, roots also received an ulterior cleaning treatment with sonication in pulse mode and output power of 20 W for about 5 min in a water-bath.
A sub-sample of bulked healthy leaves was frozen in liquid N2 immediately after collection and stored at 70 C for further analysis of antioxidant enzymes. The remaining plant tissues were oven dried at 40 C until constant weight, ground to fine powder, acid digested, and analyzed for Ce and B concentration by using ICP-OES.

sections.heading: 2.4. Determination of antioxidant enzymatic activity in sunflower plants
sections.text:
Frozen leaves (0.2 g FW) were ground under liquid nitrogen and homogenized in 2 ml of extraction buffer, consisting of 50 mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0), 1 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl-fluoride, 1 mM ascorbic acid and 2% polyvinylpolypyrrolidone (PVPP). Plant extracts were centrifuged at 20,000 g for 30 min at 4 C and the supernatants were used to measure the enzymatic activity. The SOD (EC 1.15.1.1) activity was assayed by measuring its ability to inhibit the photoreduction of nitro blue tetrazolium (NBT), according to the method of Beyer and Fridovich (1987). In this assay, one unit of SOD is defined as the amount required to inhibit the photoreduction of NBT by50%. TheCAT (EC 1.11.1.6) activitywasmeasured according toAebi (1974), bymonitoring the decomposition ofH2O2. The activity of this enzymewas calculated bymeasuring the decrease in absorbance at 240 nm for 1 min (ε ¼ 0.04 mM 1 cm 1). Ascorbate peroxidase (APX, EC 1.11.1.11) activitywas determined by following thedecrease in absorbance at 290 nm (ε ¼ 2.7 mM 1 cm 1) due to ascorbate oxidation (Nakano and Asada, 1981). Glutathione reductase (GR, EC 1.6.4.2) activity was determined by following the decrease in absorbance at 340 nm (ε ¼ 6.2 mM 1 cm 1) due to the glutathione-dependent NADPH oxidation, according to the
Please cite this article in press as: Tassi, E., et al., Physiological and biochem CeO2 and excess boron: Modulation of boron phytotoxicity, Plant j.plaphy.2016.09.013
modified method of Foyer and Halliwell (1976). In the case of CAT, APX, and GR,1 unit of activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that can oxidize 1 mmole of substrate per minute. Further experimental details are reported elsewhere (Morelli and Scarano, 2004). All enzymatic activities were calculated per mg of protein. The protein content in the cell extract was determined according to Bradford (1976) using bovine serumalbumin as standard. Enzymatic assays were carried out at 25 C using a double-beam Jasco UV/ Visible Spectrometer (Model V-550, Lecco, Italy).

sections.heading: 3.1. Main soil characteristics
sections.text:
The topsoil used in this study is characterized by a sandy loam texture with subealkaline pH, typical of Tuscany soils (Bretzel and Calderisi, 2006). Its OM content is within typical values of Italian soils (FAO, 2005) and the CEC is classified as normal to high, according to Italian Society of Soil Science (SISS, 2010), which indicates a soil with good capacity to bind cations and to provide the essential nutrients for the growth of plants. The original soil was spiked with B in order to increase its availability to plants. The

sections.heading: 3.2. Impact of CeO2 NPs on sunflower plants
3.2.1. Effect of CeO2 NPs in biomass production
sections.text:
The root, stem, and leaf biomass of plants grown in original soil (unspiked soil) was not significantly affected by the presence of nano-CeO2, at all tested concentrations (Fig. 1aec). Moreover, none of the NP treatments produced visible symptoms of toxicity in leaves or roots. Fig. 2a, for example, shows leaves and roots exposed to nano-CeO2 at 400 mg kg 1. Previous studies in soil systems have also shown no visible signs of toxicity or biomass reduction under nano-CeO2 exposure. Ma et al. (2016) observed no-effects on shoot height and total biomass at different growth stages (vegetative, floral, and seed) of Brassica rapa grown in soil irrigated with suspensions of nano-CeO2 at 10 and 100 mg kg 1. Recently, a field
mical responses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) exposed to nanoPhysiology and Biochemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
lysimeter study showed that nano-CeO2 at 100 and 400 mg kg 1 did not affect the biomass and grain yield of wheat (Triticum aestivum) (Du et al., 2015). However, different impacts on lettuce biomass were observed by Gui et al. (2015), who reported no effect on biomass at low level of CeO2 NPs (50 mg kg 1) and shoot and root biomass reduction at a very high concentration (1000 mg kg 1). Moreover, Priester et al. (2012) reported a reduced growth of roots and shoots of soybean (Glycine max) cultivated in farm soil amended with 100 mg kg 1 nano-CeO2. The different responses have been attributed to plant species, soil properties, and different levels of Ce3þ on the surface of NPs (Morales et al., 2013; Zhao et al., 2012).
In our study, increasing concentrations of nano-CeO2 in B-spiked soil did not produce a significant effect on plant biomass (Fig.1aec), compared to plants from untreated soil (0 NPs). However, in Bspiked soil, typical B phytotoxicity symptoms were evident in older leaves (significant chlorosis and necrosis), regardless the presence or absence of nano-CeO2 (Fig. 2b,c). Roots from B-spiked soil did not present any visible sign of toxicity (Fig. 2b,c). However, significant biomass reduction, respect to control (unspiked, untreated soil) was found at all NP concentrations (Fig.1a), which could be attributed to B phytotoxicity. Interestingly, the 400 mg kg 1 nano-CeO2 treatment showedno reduction of root biomass. Independently of theNP concentration in soil, the biomass from stems and leaves (Fig. 1b,c) showed no significant difference, respect to the control, although a trend in biomass reduction was observable in both tissues. It is possible that statistically significant differenceswill be observed in a longer study,which is supported by the early symptoms observed in older leaves (Fig 2).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Ce and B content in plants tissues
sections.text:
Cerium concentration in roots increased at increasing levels of nano-CeO2 (Fig. 3a), where a high positive and significant
Please cite this article in press as: Tassi, E., et al., Physiological and biochem CeO2 and excess boron: Modulation of boron phytotoxicity, Plant j.plaphy.2016.09.013
correlation (coefficient of determination R2 ¼ 0.8957, p ¼ 0.01) among Ce in roots and nano-CeO2 concentration in soil was found, suggesting that the uptake occured via simple diffusion. Although there was a huge amount of Ce in roots, very little was translocated to stems (around 0.1e0.3 mg kg 1 Ce, Fig 3b) or leaves (below detection limit of ICP-OES, DL¼ 0.1 mg L 1). In addition, there were no visible effects on roots and leaves (Fig. 2a) nor a significant influence on growth (Fig. 1a). Similar results were found by Majumdar et al. (2014) who observed a linear increase of Ce accumulation in roots of hydroponic bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) plants with low translocation to the leaves. The spectroscopic analyses suggested the entry of nano-CeO2 through the gaps in the Casparian strip at the emergence of secondary roots. Other crops or edible plants such as soybean (L opez-Moreno et al., 2010), cucumber (Cucumis sativus) (Ma et al., 2015), rice (Rico et al., 2013a,b), andmaize (Zeamays) (Birbaium et al., 2010), among others, showed higher accumulation of nano-CeO2 in the roots in a dose dependent manner. Apparently, the presence of Ce in sunflower plants did not produce a severe impact on plant development, in terms of biomass of either roots or shoots (Figs. 1 and 2). This suggests that sunflower could have an efficient tolerance mechanism. Possibly, immobilization of the nano-CeO2 is occurring in the roots, and at the same time preventing the translocation to the shoots (Hossain et al., 2012), in analogy to the most common form of heavy metal tolerance mechanism (retention at root level). The immobilization of a large fraction of heavy metals in the apoplastic space of roots or complexation at the cell wall-plasma membrane is an adaptive strategy for tolerance in plants and could be associated also to NPs or its dissociated ions. In fact, Zhao et al. (2012) observed the presence of nano-CeO2 mostly in cell walls of cortex tissues of corn plants, while Zhang et al. (2012) observed needle-like clusters of CePO4 in both the root epidermis and root intercellular spaces of hydroponic cucumber, exposed to nano-CeO2 at 2000 mg L 1.
Cerium content in sunflower tissues from B-spiked soil showed similar trend as in the original soil. In roots, a highly positive and significant correlation with NPs in the soil (Fig. 3a, empty bars, coefficient of determination R2 ¼ 0.9992 at p ¼ 0.01) suggested the uptake via simple diffusion. However, a lower amount of Ce in roots was observed, respect to plants grown in unspiked soil (Fig. 3a). This reduction was more pronounced at 100e400 mg kg 1 (around 60%) and around 40% at 800 mg kg 1 nano-CeO2 treatments. These results could indicate a reduced NPs availability for plant uptake when high levels of B were present in this specific soil. However, additional studies are needed to better understand the interaction of NPs with the B available fraction and soil constituents. Studies on soils with different properties showed that, particularly the dissolved organic matter, could increase the NPs' leaching to deeper soil and their availability for plant uptake (Lv et al., 2014; Tassi et al., 2012; Zhao et al., 2012). Conversely, a reduced mobility, and perhaps reduced availability for plant uptake have been reported, due to increasing interaction among the NPs and the active surfaces in soil (clays, oxides and/or high molecular weight organic matter) and/or due to NPs coagulation in the small pore soil (De Castro et al., 2012; Li et al., 2011; Rodrigues et al., 2016). The mobility of NPs in soils could be affected by the high ionic strength of soil porewater, which facilitates NPs' aggregation and precipitation in soil pores. The values of OM and EC of our soil system are considered within normal values for Italian soils, and no relevant soil property could be associated with plant uptake and availability of nanoCeO2.
Regarding B accumulation in plants, as expected, it was mainly transferred to the leaves; however, significant differences of B concentrationweremeasured at different levels of NPs in soil. Roots showed a similar B concentration of about 40 mg kg 1 (Fig. 4a, roots) regardless of the applied amount of nano-CeO2. Stems
ical responses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) exposed to nanoPhysiology and Biochemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
Fig. 4. Boron concentration in the different sunflower tissues from plants grown in CeO2 NPs treated soils: a) unspiked soil, b) B-spiked soil. Bars are mean values with standard deviation (n ¼ 4). Asterisks above bars * and ** denote significant differences at level p 0.05 and p 0.01, respectively, with respect to untreated soil.
generally had a B concentration around 20 mg kg 1; however, at 800mg kg 1 nano-CeO2, B concentrationwas reduced by about 30% (Fig. 4a, stems). In leaves, the presence of 100 mg kg 1 nano-CeO2 in soil did not significantly affect B accumulation, compared with control; however, at 400 and 800 mg nano-CeO2 kg 1, leaves showed a B reduction of about 37% (Fig. 4a, leaves). Moreover, a tendency of root biomass reduction, although not significantly different from the control, was observed (Fig. 1a), endorsing the roots sensibility to B reduction (Asad et al., 2003). Our results suggested that high levels of NPs in soil could interfere with B translocation from the roots to the upper parts, which give rise to a reduction of nutritional status of plants, since B is an essential micronutrient. Several studies demonstrated that B deficiency could interfere with the development and maintenance of cell wall and membrane function, nitrogen assimilation, stress response, photosynthesis and plant growth (Camacho-Crist obal et al., 2011; Cong et al., 2015; Dell and Huang, 1997). Boron deficiency in plants is also a subject of interest since it is a constraint for crop production. For example, deformed seed and low oil content on sunflower with low B levels were found by Chatterjee and Nautiyal (2000) and Eggert and von Wir en (2015). On the other hand, several metal oxide NPs impact the physiology of plants: Fe2O3 NPs reduced root hydraulic conductivity of sunflowers grown in hydroponics (Martinez-Fernadez et al., 2016); TiO2 NPs inhibited leaf
Please cite this article in press as: Tassi, E., et al., Physiological and bioche CeO2 and excess boron: Modulation of boron phytotoxicity, Plant j.plaphy.2016.09.013
growth and transpiration of hydroponic maize via physical effects on roots transport (Asli and Newman, 2009); nano-CeO2 affected nutrient and water uptake, reducing the nutrient status of rice grains (Rico et al., 2013c). It is still not known how metallic NPs influence the transport of nutrients and water through the roots; however, physical interactions between plant root tissues and NPs have been considered as a possible cause. Although further studies are needed to clarify the mechanism involved in the interference of nano-CeO2 with B nutritional status of sunflower plants, our results suggest an interaction of NPs with the available B at root level, thus reducing the B transport to the upper parts, and/or NPs' interference on the water transport system. Boric acid [B(OH)3] is the form of B mainly present in soil solution at soil pH near neutrality, and is the neutral-molecule-form of Bmostly taken up by plants. Recently, the identification of B transporters in plants suggests that the process occurs not only by a passive diffusion but also by an active transport to xylem and facilitated diffusion through channels belonging to intrinsic proteins, in response to environmental B conditions (deficiency or toxicity) tomaintain B homeostasis (Miwa and Fujiwara, 2010). On the other hand, it was demonstrated that nano-CeO2 are able to carry out redox reactions with inorganic ions. Liu et al. (2015) observed that nano-CeO2 perform redox reaction with ferrous ions, improving the colloidal stability by enhancing the zeta potential and hydrophilicity of the NPs with a potential
mical responses of sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) exposed to nanoPhysiology and Biochemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/
Fig. 5. Activity of stress enzymes in sunflower leaves from unspiked soil and B-spiked soil: a) SOD, b) CAT, c) GR, d) APX. Values are means ± SD (n ¼ 4). Different letters are significantly different (p 0.05) with respect to control soil (unspiked, untreated).
impact on their transport. Our results suggest a kind of interaction between nano-CeO2 and B(OH)3 at the root level, influencing the nutritional status of sunflower at higher levels of NPs in soil. To our knowledge, this is the first study showing the implication of nanoCeO2 on the B-nutritional status of sunflower plants.
As expected, a higher B concentrationwas found in all sunflower tissues from B-spiked soil, compared with unspiked soil (Fig. 4a,b). In particular, B in leaves increased about 10 times (660e710 mg kg 1) compared to leaves from unspiked soil (Fig. 4a,b) and chlorosis on the tip of old leaves was clearly visible (Fig. 2b,c). Moreover, a small but significant reduction of B content was observed in roots and leaves due to the presence of nano-CeO2 (Fig. 4b). Boron values in roots were significantly reduced by about 15% at 100, 200 and 800 mg kg 1 NP treatments and about 10% in leaves of plants treated with the higher concentrations of NP (400 and 800mg kg 1). These results could suggest a tendency to reduce B toxicity in nano-CeO2 treated soils, although the visible necrosis in older leaves from all NP treatments indicated a non-complete ‘alleviation’ of B toxicity in plants. This result should be further explored to provide indications of some possible beneficial effect of CeO2 NPs.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Stress enzymes in leaves
sections.text:
In order to have information on the status of plant antioxidant defense system when subject to increasing amount of NPs, sunflower leaves were evaluated for the following antioxidant enzymes: SOD, CAT, APX and GR (Fig. 5 aed). The activity of SOD, CAT, APX, and GR in leaves from plants grown under the influence of NPs did not significantly differ from the control (Fig. 5aed). However, a slight increase (not significant) in CAT activity was observed with nano-CeO2 concentrations above 200 mg kg 1, suggesting an
Please cite this article in press as: Tassi, E., et al., Physiological and biochem CeO2 and excess boron: Modulation of boron phytotoxicity, Plant j.plaphy.2016.09.013
activation of the enzyme to some extent. This result suggests that the reduction of B concentration in tissues at high NP levels, did not fall below the B critical threshold; thus, sunflower leaves did not show any appreciable oxidative stress. In fact, other studies with Bdeficient sunflower observed two- and fourfold higher peroxidase activity in leaves and roots, respectively in comparison to B-sufficient plants (El-Shinthnawy, 1999) and a decrease of GR activities, concomitant with an increase of APX (Cakmak and Romheld, 1997).
The presence of huge levels of B in sunflower leaves from Bspiked soil without NP treatments brought to a significant increase of SOD and a drastic reduction of GR, compared with leaves from control plants (Fig. 5 a, c). On the other hand, no alteration of CAT and APX activities was observed in comparison with control plants (Fig. 5 b,d). These results are in agreement with data on the involvement of stress enzymes, indicating an oxidative damage in sunflower under toxic B levels. The activation or inactivation of stress enzymes depends on several factors including plant species (Giansoldati et al., 2012), tolerant or sensible cultivars (Karabal et al., 2003), and the type of stressor, among others. At increasing amount of NPs in B-spiked soil, the SOD activity tends to decrease and restore the control value at the highest NP treatment (800 mg kg 1) (Fig. 5a), behaviour that could be hypothetically attributed to a sort of SOD-mimicking action by nano-CeO2 in plants. The activity of the other enzymes did not show influence of NPs (Fig. 5bed).
It is generally accepted that the toxicity of CeO2 NPs may be caused by the excessive production of ROS with a pro-oxidative effect. Several studies on food plants grown in soil treated with nano-CeO2 showed an overproduction of H2O2 and increase in antioxidant enzymatic activity (Du et al., 2015; Gui et al., 2015; Rico et al., 2013a). On the contrary, the anti-oxidative or ROS scavenging

activity of nano-CeO2 mimicking the action of common stress enzymes, such as SOD and CAT, has been observed in animal cells (Andreescu et al., 2014) and also in plant cells and chloroplasts (Boghossian, 2015; Corral-Diaz et al., 2014; Gomez-Garay et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2016; Rico et al., 2013b,c). SOD- and CAT-miming action was attributed to the mixed valence (Ce3þ/Ce4þ) on the surface of CeO2 NPs and the oxidation-reduction cycle between these two valence states (Xue et al., 2011). Taken together, our results suggest that the oxidative stress in plants due to high levels of B was not influenced by the presence of nano-CeO2. More studies are needed in order to fully understand the changes (or noalteration) of enzymatic activity caused by a stressor (excess of B), when a potential antioxidant factor (CeO2 NPs) is present.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The results demonstrated that Ce was accumulated in sunflower roots in a dose dependent manner, with very low translocation to the upper plant parts. In addition, no significant effects on biomass production or visible traits were observed. Although an apparent mechanism of tolerance to nano-CeO2 was demonstrated in sunflower plants, higher levels of NPs in the soil resulted in a detrimental effect on B nutritional status (reduction of about 30%) of plants grown in original soil. However, there was only a marginal reduction in B concentration (about 10%) in plants grown with excess of B, which could indicate a sort of counteraction by nanoCeO2. In addition, plants from the original soil with reduced B status showed no observable and sensible oxidative stress in leaves, while plants with high levels of B showed amodulation of the antioxidant defense system. However, further studies are needed to better understand the effects and interactions between nano-CeO2 and B in the soil-plant system.

metadata.abstractText: Little is known about the interaction of nanoparticles (NPs) with soil constituents and their effects in plants. Boron (B), an essential micronutrient that reduces crop production at both deficiency and excess, has not been investigated with respect to its interaction with cerium oxide NPs (nano-CeO2). Considering conflicting results on the nano-CeO2 toxicity and protective role as antioxidant, their possible modulation on B toxicity in sunflower (Helianthus annuus L.) was investigated. Sunflower was cultivated for 30 days in garden pots containing original or B-spiked soil amended with nano-CeO2 at 0e800 mg kg 1. At harvest, Ce and B concentrations in tissues, biomass, and activities of stress enzymes in leaves were determined. Results showed that in the original soil, Ce accumulated mainly in roots, with little translocation to stems and leaves, while reduced root Ce was observed in plants from B-spiked soil. In the original soil, higher levels of nano-CeO2 reduced plant B concentration. Although morphological effects were not visible, changes in biomass and oxidative stress response were observed. Sunflower leaves from B-spiked soil showed visible symptoms of B toxicity, such as necrosis and chlorosis in old leaves, as well as an increase of superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity. However, at high nano-CeO2 level, SOD activity decreased reaching values similar to that of the control. This study has shown that nano-CeO2 reduced both the B nutritional status of sunflower in original soil and the B phytotoxicity in B-spiked soil. © 2016 Elsevier Masson SAS. All rights reserved.
